column1: Before 1 January 2024, will Elizabeth "Liz" Truss cease to be prime minister of the United Kingdom?
column6: ['Leader Entry/Exit', 'Non-US Politics']
i messed up
A done deal.
It seems Liz Truss will have managed to make two "in the news in 2023" questions resolve two months before 2023. Impressive.
Well, when I’m wrong, I’m wildly wrong.
Resignation announced
reporting today seems to indicate this is imminent - https://www.cnbc.com/2022/10/20/uk-prime-minister-liz-truss-resigns-after-failed-budget-and-market-turmoil.html

"Liz Truss almost as unpopular as Prince Andrew as 80% hold ‘unfavorable’ view of PM." There are other stories out there that show between 80-90% is her disapproval rating. Between 50-60% want her out of office. Signals for this rating change would be country's 4th Quarter economic results.
My initial forecast was 65% then I changed my mind mostly by reading all the comments here. Mistake. I’d rather come back to my previous forecast slightly adjusting up.
Chaos in Parliament and another cabinet member sacked.
Truss is going to get trussed.

The press is full of articles about the debacle created by Truss. See https://www.bloomberg.com/news/videos/2022-10-19/truss-s-premiership-looks-close-to-imploding?sref=x7nYEkiY and https://www.nytimes.com/2022/10/18/opinion/liz-truss-uk-hunt.html.

https://www.nytimes.com/2022/10/18/opinion/liz-truss-uk-hunt.html?campaign_id=2&emc=edit_th_20221019&instance_id=75023&nl=todaysheadlines&regi_id=77825025&segment_id=110400&user_id=dc6933c94fc82416d25dd297622374d1
Home secretary is out (for reasons unclear right now). https://twitter.com/PippaCrerar/status/1582753580746174465
Resignations and/or sacking going on this morning.
77% disapproval rate. 69% among conservatives. That is just insane.

The fact the British people at large and her own party seem to be all for it makes this seem very likely. Also, unlike many positions in office, the UK PM office looks to be a nimble one as of late where being cast by tomatoes and popcorn would be a promise to end things.
Her day are numbered apparently
Front pages of British newspapers, today (Oct 18): https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2022/oct/18/the-ghost-pm-what-the-papers-say-about-liz-trusss-hold-on-power
This is a necessary change to my forecast, in line with my reasoning for the similar question with a 1 April 2023 end date: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1527223
forgot to add comments...(pulling these over from the other question about Liz Truss/prior to Jan 1, 2024.

Her economic policies have caused a lot of political upheaval against her leadership. The calls for her to be replaced are growing. There are multiple articles out there on it. Additionally, Biden came out and said he didn't support their policies. I'm bumping up 5% for now.
See here for the latest updates (at least until tomorrow): https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1526375

Honestly don't see a way out for Truss at this point. Rumours of 100 letters of confidence are already in, with 54 being the threshold to hold a vote of no confidence in normal times i.e., after her first 12 months during which she is, in principle, protected against such a vote. The new chancellor hasn't done anything to restore confidence in her, supporting the theory that he's just there as a caretaker to transition to the next PM. If the markets are red tomorrow it will further bury Truss.
There has been a slew of PMs of late and with her serious errors right out of the gate... How could she manage to stay?
https://twitter.com/lewis_goodall/status/1581703318019403777
Updates on the recent plans to remove her sooner rather than later in the other relevant question: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1525836

This has gone off the charts very fast; bookies now give odds implying a probability of ~ 55% that she will leave before January 2023. And Daily Star has set a live feed wondering if she will outlast... a lettuce!!!https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Sm-RE95lKJ0https://www.reuters.com/world/uk/can-liz-truss-outlast-lettuce-uk-tabloid-asks-twitter-post-2022-10-14/https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/2022/10/15/liz-truss-lettuce-daily-star-economy/

Well, who knows what will happen next. Truss may have bought herself some time by replacing Kwarteng with Hunt and backing off the tax cuts. But it has completely ruined her credibility. Hunt looks like he is going to step in and present himself as a safe set of hands which would set him up nicely to replace Truss. But Johnson and Sunak are in the wings with Mordant snapping at their heels, let alone Labour!

Today The Atlantic published this very negative opinion piece on Liz Truss. https://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2022/10/liz-truss-fires-kwasi-kwarteng-tax-cuts-britain/671738/. I'll bump the odds to 60/40.
Full on collapse. Cringeworthy.
This is moving very fast

Keir Starmer is now calling for a general election. https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2022/oct/14/keir-starmer-uk-election-now-liz-truss-stays-goes-labourHe's usually not the first to call for things (e.g., repeatedly not calling for Boris to resign for a long time) so Labour must feel like a general election soon is a real possibility.

Does the sacking of the finance minister, Kwasi Kwarteng, increase or decrease Truss's chances of survival? See https://www.nytimes.com/live/2022/10/14/world/uk-finance-minister-truss-kwarteng. It is an admission of error.
Updated due to current blowback regarding tax issues.
There's already a new chancellor in Jeremy Hunt. https://news.sky.com/story/jeremy-hunt-made-chancellor-after-liz-truss-sacks-kwasi-kwarteng-12720267

Going up as a result of Truss sacking Kwarteng so soon. https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2022/oct/14/liz-truss-press-conference-u-turn-corporation-tax-kwasi-kwartengIn the words of Malcolm Tucker, "The PM is not going to sack you after a week. Sacked after 12 months - looks live you've fucked up. Sacked after a week - looks like he's [sic] fucked up". It's one thing to have disastrous policies - it's standard at this point - but it's another to sack your chancellor barely a month in the job after they start implementing policies you explicitly laid out during your election campaign two months ago. There's no reason to believe Kwarteng will go quietly (https://twitter.com/faisalislam/status/1580878071506227200), no one in their right mind will want to take over as chancellor, guaranteeing another mess is in the pipeline, and everyone in cabinet is now clear that the PM may fire them for doing what she wanted in the first place, let alone if they don't do what she wants, so the knives will be out ath this point and there isn't even a need to wait for a mistake to be made as that's already been done.Moreover, I don't think Truss has demonstrated the survival instinct that Boris clearly had and won't have anything to fall back on (e.g., "getting brexit done" and vaccines). PMQs next week should be lively...
The Tories are discussing her sacking. It seems she won't make it till 2024.

I previously thought that the most likely path to Liz Truss being removed was a vote of no confidence in the house of commons (https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1514802), which now does seem to be in the minds of some tory MPs after what appears to be a terrible performance by Truss in front of her MPs. With this question ending in 2024, there is a reasonable amount of time for this to happen so I will adjust upward now that the idea is clearly being floated, even if it remains to be seen if enough tory MPs could be convinced to vote against the government* (or abstain in greater numbers).
reaffirming for now.
This article in NYT gives some background information about the economic philosophy of Liz Truss. The author is decidedly not sympathetic to her views.
She's in trouble.

I think I follow the analytics of fellow forecasters + acknowledge that Tory may be afraid too loose election that such move would mean. Ms Truss started terribly but as cynical as it sounds she is still Tory.
Moving the odds down a bit. It's early days for this question; I don't want to go all in.
I think an election is unlikely, and I doubt Truss will resign in the near term - I'm sure she thinks she can turn things around.

Updating down 10% based on party rules not allowing a confidence vote on the leader within the first 12 months of their election. Including time to hold the vote, the timeline to remove Truss before Jan. 1, 2024 starts to get tight. (I think an election is exceedingly unlikely, and I doubt Truss will resign in the near term - I'm sure she thinks she can turn things around).
Her first major initiative resulted in a U-turn after a huge backlash. This is going to impact her credibility and the credibility of Tories as a whole.

Even if the markets recover and financial confidence is restored through spending and welfare cuts (which seems to the government's intent) there is unlikely to be any significant growth with rising interest rates and the impact this has on household budgets. The prospects of a majority of the 2019 Conservative intake losing their seats will lead to a confidence vote and the emergence of a compromise electable candidate. For a new party leader to require such robust defence so soon makes survival look remote.
51% of Britons think Truss should resign. See
Increasing the odds because of the mini-budget.
Buzz on various channels that no vote of confidence letters have started.
Events will overwhelm her government.

Fyi, it's worth remembering that with the conservative rules as they are currently, Truss cannot face a party vote of no confidence in her first 12 months. Unless the rules are changed, this would mean that the earliest point at which Truss could face a party vote of no confidence is September, which would leave her as PM until November if it takes another two months to elect a new conservative party leader. Much can change by then, and it may also not make sense for the party to get someone new in place just to have them lose an election in a year or so. (If it does not look the party would lose the next election, that would be an improvement so why ditch Truss?)

With 15 months to go I'll jump into this one with a 50/50 chance, vs the crowd at 31%. It is generally accepted that the recent tax cuts in the UK are a mistake. There is also a theory that the ultimate objective is to dismantle the welfare state, which is very popular.
She's gotten off to a very bad start in a very short time. And the bad start would have been sooner if the Queen hadn't died.
Going up a little because things are deteriorating so rapidly. She has a lot of bad months ahead of her.
Pressures from a rapidly worsening economy

I have to up the probability because the economy doesn’t look to bright and the “mini budget” does not look to have been the wisest. Plus there are lots of outside forces that might make things difficult to keep a government in place until 2024
-next general election is in 2025, and there are reports that Truss my call for one in 2024, which would be early
Reducing to a more reasonable historical baserate and consideration of internal circumstances, but 2023 could be a geopolitical whirlwind, and hard to imagine Truss accomplishing much.
Jumping up to ~consensus for now.

There would be no appetite from within the Conservative Party for another leadership challenge at this stage, and were one to become likely then a General Election would be called at that point. This being the case, the Conservatives will prioritise internal stability over further challenge and the Truss government will require time to offer proof of the effectiveness of current economic strategy so is unlikely to be in a position to call an early election.
Anecdotal Tory MP reports of letters of no confidence already being submitted to the 1922.
I doubt, that would be a really short amount of time. Boris lasted 3 years, surely she can last 16 months
She's a less entertaining Boris Johnson.

After reading @404_NOT_FOUND's rationale here {https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1506335}, I'm shocked Boris Johnson lasted so long given so many controversies and obstacles. So if he lasted a few years, then Liz Truss may last a little longer. Then degrade whatever resulting estimate because of new challenges like the "tanking" economy. I
5% for scandal or because the party want her to.
In 2024 UK will experience civil disorder and Truss's response will be authoritarian and ineffective.
The focus of both parties will be the 2024 election rather than causing additional de-stabilization to the government before hand.

Liz Truss has presented herself as Boris Johnson's successor and as a Margaret Thatcher lite, two things the British public doesn't need right now. She is one scandal away from a vote of no confidence. All biases aside, the cost of living crisis could be the cause of her downfall. If she is seen to be too pro-small government, cuts too many taxes for her pals and under-invest in essential services, people will be out on the streets. Will Britain go to war between now and 2024, today that is not on the cards but could be a helpful distraction for the people to focus on nationalism rather than the decline at home. Lest not forget, she was popular with the members but not the parliamentarians...
The last prime minister to serve less than 2 years in office was in 1964.

Base rate chance for this to happen are pretty slim as recent history suggests that almost all PMs last longer than 16 months. Turmoil in the conservative party suggests that a change in premiership is not excessively improbable.

Average term length for Prime Ministers (overall, for Tories, for females and female Tories) suggests a certain stability to the office in spite of economic performance of the UK (currently very bad) or approval ratings of the incumbent (currently in favour of opposition). With a comfortable majority in the House of Commons, Truss is highly likely to remain in office until the next election, which the Labour party is likely to win according to current polls.
Reasons why Truss' tenure might be short:
Thanks to @Polymorpheus @Eolienne for their analysis.
With an 80+ seat majority she has no reason to call an early election. May 2024 is most likely date for an election. She won't be getting rid of herself
The next election is due no later than Jan 25 so this question required either an early general election to resolve and the Conservatives losing, or Liz Truss to be replaced as PM.
PM Truss has many challenges she must handle as the new PM. If she cannot address inflation and other ongoing issues it is entirely possible she will cease to be PM of the United Kingdom.

Situation is a little more fraught than usual, but I don't see any particular reason for an early election barring the Tories seeing an opportunity to capitalize on strong polling, and they seem unlikely to cast aside yet another leader within about a year of electing her?
While there is a possibility that Liz Truss will flop as a prime minister, I am confident that she will remain in office for at least the foreseeable future.

at the latest the next UK general election will be January 2025 (1 year post question closure); however, with the death of queen elizabeth II, however, since the most recent election was based on only registered member votes and not general UK sentiment - there could be a push for an earlier election (the 2019 election occurred prior to the required timeline for elections.
Slim chance. The opportunity to bask in the reflected glory of the pageantry of the 'changing of the guard' at Buckingham Palace.
accounting for the possibility of the unexpected
Keeping it non zero for happenstance..
Nah, the desperate buggers will hold on to power until the end of the parliament term, claiming they have to deal with the various crisises of their own making.

Tories will try very hard to avoid replacing Truss, it took Johnson promoting a sex predator (that he knew prior about) alongside breaking his own laws for him to finally be removed. Tories deficit quite stubborn and will be unlikely Truss feels confident in doing a May and calling election in 2023.
Only one of sixteen PMs since WW2 have served a such a short term: https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_prime_ministers_of_the_United_Kingdom

The new leader of the Conservative Party now has the unenviable task of steering the UK through a tough winter and beyond. She wants to cut taxes, and control inflation, and she wants a growth strategy. She is also advocating an increase in defense spending to 3% of GDP.
Only 20% of PMs have lasted < (1 yr, 114 days)... one of which was in the 20th century. Statistically very unlikely outcome.
It is more probable than not.
Going with the bookies, for starters
She's
1. in post-colonial UK, pretty much every prime minister has crossed this mark
context: https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-politics-62064552
given the rate of ceasing prime ministers in the last 6 years, there is some chance it happens again.
